argumentText:
Let $X$ be a smooth manifold, and let $\omega$ be a closed differential
form of degree $k>0$ on $X$. For any $x\in X$, there exists a
contractible neighbourhood $U\subset X$ of $x$ (i.e. $U$ is homotopy
equivalent to a single point), with inclusion map
$$\iota\colon U\hookrightarrow X.$$ To construct such a neighbourhood,
take for example an open ball in a coordinate chart around $x$. Because
of the homotopy invariance of de Rham cohomology, the $k$th de Rham
cohomology group ${\rm H}^k(U)$ is isomorphic to that of a point; in
particular, $${\rm H}^k(U)=0\quad\hbox{for all $k>0$}.$$ Since
$d(\iota^*\omega)=\iota^*(d\omega)=0$, this implies that there exists a
$(k-1)$-form $\eta$ on $U$ such that $d\eta=\iota^*\omega$. In the case
where $X$ is a contractible manifold, such an $\eta$ exists globally
since we can choose $U=X$ above.
